note.p: Ukhaidir is a large, rectangular fortress erected in 775 AD with a unique defensive style. Constructed by the Abbasid caliph As-Saffah's nephew Isa ibn Musa.

Received
7
Sp
September
1921
Baghdad July 31
Dearest Father . I sent you a word this week by air in
answer to you letter of June 28; I must now give you an account
of our doings. Overshadowing all else was the display at
Ramadi . Fakhri Jamil Zadah + I left at 4 am but Faisal
was a little in front of us. We caught him up at Naqtab,
half way to the Euphrates + asked leave to go ahead so that
I might photograph his arrival at Fallujah . Outside that
village a couple of big tents were pitched in the desert +
for several miles crowds of tribal horsemen gathered in
+ stood along the track as he passed. We sat
in the tents - first in one, then in the other, so as to
honour both the shaikhlings of the
Dulaim Arab royal tribe\u003b dating back to pre-Islamic era. Largest Sunnni tribe in Iraq.
who had
pitched them - drinking coffee + iced
sharbats Drink prepared from fruit or flower petals.
. Then
we drove through Fallujah which was all decorated
+ packed with people. The tribesmen lined the
road to the ferry - some 6 miles - rode round,
after + beside the cars (I was immediately behind
Faisal) amid incredible clouds of dust. At the
ferry we found a big Dulaim tent + Mahrut of the 'Anizah,
Fahad Beg 's son. Here Faisal held a majlis after
which we had a small meal, sitting round dishes
set on the floor, rice + chicken + curds. It was
8.30 by this time + I was hungry. Faisal + I + one
or two others crossed in a small boat while
the motors came over the flying bridge. On the
other side Fahad Beg was waiting for him - it was a great
moment because for Fahad has been bitterly opposed to an Arab
Govt Government
+ to Faisal because he represented the hated thing which
was not British. As good luck would have it he
had received a day or two before a

threatening letter from Ibn Sa'ud telling him that his 'Anizah
were Ibn Sa'ud 's subjects + that (which they are not) +
bidding him beware of consequences if he served any
"miserable little fool of an Arab" who happened to be set up
in Mesopotamia. Fahad might serve us because we were
Ibn Sa'ud's friends, but no one else. This letter Fahad
hastened to confide to Faisal in whom he found a
sympathetic audience! (This is not to be repeated - Sir
Percy will square Ibn Sa'ud who has got a bit above
himself.)
Under the steep edge of the Syrian desert were drawn up the fighting men
of the 'Anizah, horsemen + camel riders, bearing the huge
standard of the tribe. We stopped to salute it as we passed.
'Ali Sulaiman the chief of the
Dulaim Arab royal tribe\u003b dating back to pre-Islamic era. Largest Sunni tribe in iraq.
+ one of the
most remarkable men in 'Iraq came out of
Ramadi to meet us. He has been strongly +
consistently pro-British + takes Faisal on our
recommendation only. The town was gaily decorated
+ we walked through applauding people to our
lodgings, Faisal to Major Yetts 's house, Fakhri +
I to the Mutasarrif, old Rashid Beg al 'Umari -
he was among the crowd you saw at Mosul ,
terrifically well born, but otherwise no good. I washed
+ changed - we were grey with dust - + drove
down to the Euphrates bank where Ali Sulaiman
had pitched a huge tent of ten poles - ie about
200 ft long - with a dais at the upper end covered roofed
with tent cloth + walled with fresh green boughs.
Outside were drawn up the camel riders of the
Dulaim, their horsemen + their standard carried by a

2
negro mounted on a gigantic white camel; inside the
tribesmen lined the tent 5 or 6 deep from the dais to
the very end. Faisal sat on the high diwan with Fahad
on his right while Major Yetts + I brought up people to sit
on his left - those we thought he ought to speak to. He
was supremely happy - a great tribesman amongst
famous tribes +, as I couldn't help feeling, a great
Sunni among Sunnis. The truth is I'm becoming a
Sunni myself; you know where you are with them,
they are staunch + they are guided, according to their
lights, by reason; whereas with the
Shi'ahs An Islamic sect who believe that the descendents of the Prophet Muhammad are the rightful leaders of Islam.
, however
well intentioned they may be, at any moment some
ignorant fanatic of an
'alim Educated scholar of Islamic law.
may tell them that
by the order of God + himself they are to think differently.
There it was - Faisal was in his own country
with the people he knew. I never saw him look so
splendid. He wore his usual white robes with a fine
black
abba Loose over-garment
over them, flowing white headdress + silver-
bound 'aqal. Then he began to speak, leaning forward
over the small table in front of him, sitting with
his hand raised + bringing it down onto the table to
emphasize his sentences. The people at the end of
the tent were too far off to hear; he called
them all up + they sat on the ground below the
dais, rows + rows of them, 400 or 500 men. He spoke
in the great tongue of the desert, which I had never
heard him use before, sonorous, magnificent -
no language like it. He spoke as a tribal chief to
his feudatories. "For four years" he said ''I've not found
myself in a place like this or in such company" -

you could see how he was loving it. Then he told them
how Iraq was to rise on their endeavours with himself
at their head. "Oh Arabs, are you at peace with
one another?" They shouted: "Yes, yes, we are at peace."
"From this day - what is the date? - + what
is the hour?" - someone answered him. "From
this day the 25th of July (only he gave the Mohammadan
date) + the hour of the morning 11 (it was 11 o'clock)
any tribesman who lifts his hand against a
tribesmen is responsible to me. I will judge between
you, calling in your
shaikhs Honorific title meaning 'Elder', used for leaders of tribes and royal family members.
in counsel. I
have my rights over you as your Lord -"
A grey bearded man interrupted: "And our
rights?" "And you have your rights as
subjects which it is my business to guard."
So it went on, the tribesmen interrupting him with
shouts of "Yes, yes", "We agree", "Yes by God." It
was like the descriptions of great tribal gatherings
in the Days of Ignorance, before the Prophet,
when the poets recited verse which has come
down to this day + the people shouted at the
end of each phrase: "The truth, by God
the truth!"
When it was over Fahad + Ali Sulaiman stood
up on either side of him, + said "We swear
allegiance to you because you are acceptable to
the British Government." Faisal was a little
surprised. He looked quickly round to me, smiling,
+ then he said "No one can doubt what my relations

3
are to the British, but we must settle our affairs
between ourselves." He looked at me again + I held
out my two hands clasped together as a symbol
of the union of the Arab + British Governments.
It was a tremendous moment, those two really big
men who have played their part in the history of
their time, + Faisal between them, the finest living
representative of his race - + the link ourselves.
One after another 'Ali Sulaiman brought up his
shaikhs, some 40 or 50 of them. They laid their hands
in Faisal's + swore allegiance. After that we relapsed
into chat accompanied by coffee + I told Faisal,
how splendid I had thought his speech, while 'Ali
superintended the bringing in of the largest meal
you ever witnessed. Eight men staggered under
the each rice dish, each of which was crowned
by a sheep roasted whole. We eat first, Faisal
+ his suite + we British officers, Fahad + a
few more. Then we sat on the dais watching
the others eat. Ali, as host, superintending the
sitting down + rising up of the feasting tribesmen.
And then it being long past noon + pretty hot, we
went back to our houses. I had a bath + went
to sleep till 5.
The afternoon's ceremony was the swearing of
allegiance on the part of the towns. From Fallujah to
Qaim , the northern frontier, all the Mayors,
qadhis A Muslim judge who renders decisions according to Islamic law.
+
notables had come in. The place was a palm garden.
There was a high dais built up against a blank house wall
which was hung with carpets. On this Faisal + the

rest of us sat while the elders + notables, sitting in rows under the
trees, got up, stepped on stepped onto the dais + laid
their hands in his. At the end he made a little speech, very
simple + suitable, saying that he called on God to help him
+ them in their task of regeneration. "And I have great
hope of success" - he turned to Major Yetts + me - "because
of the benevolent race which gives us its support." The
beauty of the setting, the variety of dress + colour,
the grave faces of the village elders, white turbaned
or draped in the red Arab kerchief + the fine
dignity with which Faisal accepted the homage offered to
him made the scene almost as striking as that of
the morning.
When that was over we all walked in procession
through the town, Faisal first. Then we went to
Major Yetts's house where Faisal had private
interviews with Shaikhs, while I had some
delightful talks with all my friends from far +
near many of whom I hadn't seen for some time.
Till dusk sunset we sat in the courtyard + then went up
onto the roof which was carpeted + set with
diwans + chairs. We all chatted very informally
till dinner, Faisal very eager to know about
ancient monuments - Fahad + I told him
about Ukhaidhir which is in Fahad's desert pasturages.
The leading citizen of the town was meantime
engaged in having dinner brought for us. It was
laid on the floor + we eat, about 30 of us.
There is a great deal to be said for an Arab

4
dinner party. All the viands are before you, you eat
what you want + when you're done you get up
+ go back to your coffee + cigarettes. Faisal ,
accustomed to this, is very impatient at
European dinners - he always wants to
leave the table the moment he has finished.
After a little more talk I took my leave + went
to bed on the Mutasarrif 's roof. It was all hung
with the
Hijaz flags Refers to the Hejaz flag, which was used during the Arab Revolt against the Ottoman Empire.
+ as I lay down in my bed
I fell to thinking how pleasant it was to be sleeping
as peacefully + naturally under the Sharifian
flag as under the British.
We motored back to Baghdad next day, starting
before dawn + getting in at 9.
Since when we've had alarums + excursions in Baghdad.
The group of extremists made a desperate effort - +
succeeded - to substitute for the official formula of
allegiance one which implied the complete rejection of
the British. They called a packed meeting, more than
half
Shi'ahs An Islamic sect who believe that the descendants of the Prophet Muhammad are the rightful leaders of Islam.
, + the evening before the voting referendum papers were
to be issued, amid a wild confusion of talk
about
Fatwahs A non-binding judgment on a point of Islamic law given by a recognized religious authority.
(i.e. of the Shi'ah
'alims An educated scholar of Islamic law.
) added
their clauses to the papers. In this form they were
signed in every city quarter next day to the disgust,
indignation of the
Sunni An Islamic sect who do not believe that the descendants of the Prophet Muhammad are the rightful leaders of Islam.
notables who had kept as
informed of the whole business. Faisal sent for Muhammad
Sadr , who was at the bottom of it, + gave him
fair warning that now that he was practically king

Fortunately when read carefully they proved to be complete nonsense + all the young + illuminated
scoffed at them, while I sent to two of my newspaper men + got articles in that sense into
their papers. Ridicule is the deadliest arm.

he didn't intend to stand any nonsense + any one who
disturbed the public mind should be suitably dealt
with. He topped this by a very judicious speech
yesterday morning at an allegiance ceremony held
for him by the Christian communities. He said
"We have suffered under 800 years of tyranny;
give me a year for every hundred, a year for
every two hundred, + with the preservation of peace
you shall see what we can do." And then he
went on to point out that no nation stands
alone - it forms part of the community of peoples.
The Arabs above all were in want of help
"+ where shall we turn for help but to the
nation nearest to us, economically + geographically,
the British? I ask them for help as a free
man to a free people, as a friend to a friend."
I went to tea with him in the evening; Mr
Cornwallis dropped in presently + we had a
long + very amusing talk. I took him the
photographs I had done at Ramadi with
which he was much delighted, + then we freely
cursed all the people we didn't like + discussed.
what he should do to them. On the way back
I met Sir Aylmer who had been trying to call
on me, so I carried him back with me. He
stayed till dinner time while I related the
events of the past few days, to his deep interest.

5.
He is playing up like a man, immensely eager
to make the thing go, loves Faisal + does all
he can to help on the Arab army.
There! I really can't write any more.
Would you very kindly send a copy of the Ramadi
part to Milly - exclusive of what I said
about Ibn Saud + Fahad . I owe her answers
to many delightfully interesting letters from
Canada . I must spend the rest of this
Sunday morning on my Fortnightly report for
the
Sec.
Secretary
of State .
( Domnul may see the whole letter +
all my letters.)
I'm immensely happy about this thing - the
referendum has gone through unanimously with but for
the sole exception of Kirkuk where the population,
half Turkish + half Kurdish, has been
difficult to handle. I think we may just squeeze
it through there also. We are now waiting for
the Mosul + Hillah papers to come in to declare
Faisal king. He may possibly be crowned next
week. Isn't that very remarkable! 5 weeks' work.
Your devoted daughter
Gertrude

On His Majesty's Service.
Sir Hugh Bell Bart C B
Rounton Grange
Northallerton
England
